speaker: Speaker_1
text: Well, you know, I'm on a computer mailing list on my e-mail.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: It's a research thing for psycholinguistics.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: And at UPenn, they're building a linguistic database of many languages, and so they were offering free phone calls anywhere in the world.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: We have to only speak one language, though.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: So they're collecting lots of different languages, but you have to only speak the two parties have to speak the same language.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: So I could only call a native English speaker.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: You shouldn't be throwing in lots of German.

speaker: Speaker_2
text: I should be or I shouldn't be?

speaker: Speaker_1
text: I know that will be hard, but I decided to go for it anyway.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: And they're doing Tamil and French and German and all different languages.

speaker: Speaker_2
text: But are they really going to record this?

speaker: Speaker_2
text: Are they really going to use it for something?

speaker: Speaker_1
text: My guess is that it's either for doing some sort of speech recognition systems for computers or for building up.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: There's a field called computational linguistics where they look at the properties of languages, what the probabilities are of various kinds of words occurring together and such.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: So I'm guessing that's what it's for and they need to learn it.

speaker: Speaker_2
text: Anyway, thank you very much for your note and your card and your photo a couple weeks ago.

speaker: Speaker_1
text: Yeah, and how are your grandkids?

speaker: Speaker_1
text: Did Judy have the second one?

speaker: Speaker_2
text: She had the second one in March.

speaker: Speaker_2
text: And so he's about three months old.

speaker: Speaker_2
text: And, of course, Patrick is talking and walking.
